gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: NOAA/NESDIS Advanced Himawari Imager (AHI) Level 2 Cloud Mask (CM) from Himawari 8

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: DOC/NOAA/NESDIS/STAR > Center for Satellite Applications and Research, NESDIS, NOAA, U.S. Department of Commerce
DOC/NOAA/NESDIS/STAR > Center for Satellite Applications and Research, NESDIS, NOAA, U.S. Department of Commerce
DOC/NOAA/NESDIS/STAR > Center for Satellite Applications and Research, NESDIS, NOAA, U.S. Department of Commerce

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: This dataset contains a high quality level 2 cloud mask product from the Advanced Himawari Imager (AHI) instrument onboard the Himawari-8 satellite that is operated by the Japanese Meteorological Agency (JMA) and is produced operationally by the NOAA Environmental Satellite, Data, and Information Service (NESDIS). The algorithm retrieval utilizes AHI channel brightness temperatures and reflectances to produce cloud mask data products. AHI has 16 spectral bands with spatial resolutions ranging from 0.5 or 1 km for visible and near-infrared bands, and 2 km for infrared bands. Himawari-8 provides Full Disk and regional mesoscale coverage of the Asia-Pacific region approximately every 10 and 2.5 minutes respectively. Himawari-8 data produced by NESDIS are in NetCDF version 4 (NetCDF4) format with metadata attributes included and are disseminated to users via multiple paths, including Internet cloud services and communication satellite services.

gmd:purpose.gco:CharacterString: The Cloud Mask product can be used by the NWP community to identify which AHI pixel information should be assimilated for use in numerical weather prediction models.

gmd:fileDescription.gco:CharacterString: Example of the Cloud Mask product as generated by the Himawari-8 Cloud Mask algorithm.

gmi:description.gco:CharacterString: Produces multi-purpose imagery for weather and environment monitoring, NWP utilization; and wind derivation by tracking clouds and water vapor.
Himawari 8 is a Japanese weather satellite, the 8th of the Himawari geostationary weather satellites operated by the Japan Meteorological Agency.
